Enforce data and action boundaries so one tenant cannot affect another

recommendation: Use Tenant as the canonical term for isolated customer environments managed by MSPs. Use Customer or Client in business-facing contexts.

definition: Traffic refers to the flow of data packets transmitted across a network between devices, services, or endpoints. It includes both inbound and outbound communication and can represent various protocols (e.g., HTTP, DNS, SSH) and applications. In MSP and IT operations, monitoring traffic is essential for performance analysis, bandwidth management, anomaly detection, and security threat identification.
relationships: Traffic isMonitoredBy Firewall, NetworkProbe, or AI Agent
Traffic influences Bandwidth, Latency, or QoS
prompt_examples: Analyze outbound traffic from the finance VLAN over the past 24 hours.
Block all traffic to known malicious IPs using the firewall policy.
Summarize HTTP traffic patterns by device for the last 7 days.
Detect unusual traffic spikes to external DNS servers.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to “Traffic,” the AI agent will:
actions: Query network flow data, packet captures, or traffic logs from monitoring tools
Aggregate or filter traffic by protocol, source, destination, port, or time window
Detect anomalies or threshold violations such as unusual spikes or unauthorized destinations
Correlate traffic patterns with known risks or baseline behaviors
Trigger appropriate actions such as alerting, blocking, throttling, or logging based on configured policies

recommendation: Use Traffic to refer to network data flows for monitoring and security. Specify protocol, source, destination, or time frame to refine queries and actions.

definition: A User is an individual identity that interacts with or is managed by the ecosystem. The term User may refer to two distinct but related concepts. In the DevOps Infrastructure Ontology, a User is typically a human actor who interacts with resources and services, often through a UI, command line, or API. A user may represent different roles depending on the context, including an MSP administrator, IT technician, end user (someone logging into a managed device), or N-able support personnel. A user may also be a leaf node representing a person managed as part of a customer environment. Users can be associated with specific tenants, organizations, roles, or permissions, and their activities may be logged, audited, and constrained by policies. It is not recommended to use the term User without additional context.
relationships: User isAssignedTo Tenant, MSP, or Site
User hasRole (e.g., Admin, Viewer, Operator, Support)
User isLoggedInVia Asset | Device or WebSession
prompt_examples: List all users with admin access to tenant ‘BlueNet Solutions’.
Has the end user ‘alex.jordan’ logged in from multiple locations recently?
Disable the user account for ‘tech.msmith’ across all N-central-managed environments.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to a “User,” the AI Agent will:
actions: Resolve the identity context (e.g., MSP admin, end user, support tech)
Look up associated permissions, roles, tenant ownership, and login history
Take actions such as listing access, modifying roles, disabling users, or flagging suspicious activity
Use multi-tenant scoping rules to ensure actions are authorized and logged appropriately
Disambiguate prompts like “user logged into the asset” vs. “user with N-able product access”

recommendation: Use User with added context specifying role, scope, or identity type to avoid ambiguity.

definition: A Version is a specific state or release of a software application, configuration, operating system, firmware, or document that reflects its development or deployment stage. Versions are used to track changes, ensure compatibility, and manage updates across environments. In MSP and IT operations, versioning is critical for patching, compliance, supportability, and rollback planning.
relationships: Version appliesTo Software, Device, OS, Policy, or Script
Version isTrackedIn Inventory, Patch Manager, or CMDB
Version mayTrigger Update, Alert, or Compatibility Check
Version isReportedIn Device Summary or Compliance Report
prompt_examples: List all devices running a version of Chrome older than 115.
Is the backup agent version compatible with the current OS version?
Update all endpoints to the latest version of the RMM agent.
Which scripts have multiple versions saved in the automation library?

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to a “Version,” the AI agent will:
actions: Identify the current version of the referenced object
Compare it to known baselines, approved versions, or available updates
Initiate version-specific actions such as patching, blocking, or rollback
Surface compatibility warnings or compliance gaps when mismatched
Log version changes, comparisons, and actions for auditing or reporting

recommendation: Use Version to track and manage software or configuration states. Specify the object and version context to ensure accurate actions.

definition: VMware is a widely used virtualization and cloud infrastructure platform that enables the creation, management, and operation of virtual machines (VMs) and virtualized environments. VMware products support server, desktop, and network virtualization, allowing multiple workloads to run on shared physical hardware. In MSP and IT environments, VMware is often integrated for infrastructure management, backup, monitoring, and automation.
relationships: VMware isMonitoredBy Agent, Probe, or SNMP
VMware integratesWith Backup, Discovery, and Patch Tools
VMware exposes Metrics, Inventory, and ConfigurationData
prompt_examples: List all VMware hosts with over 80 percent CPU usage.
Backup all virtual machines in the VMware cluster nightly.
Which VMware guest VMs are running outdated tools?
Add the new ESXi host to the existing VMware inventory group.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to “VMware,” the AI agent will:
actions: Connect to the VMware environment via vSphere API or integration endpoint
Retrieve inventory and configuration data on hosts, VMs, and resource usage
Monitor performance metrics and status indicators for virtualization health
Execute tasks such as backup, VM tagging, or automated provisioning
Log interactions and changes for audit and compliance reporting

recommendation: Use VMware to refer specifically to virtualization infrastructure and management. Specify hosts, VMs, or clusters for detailed queries and actions.

definition: A Vulnerability is a weakness or flaw in software, hardware, or configuration that could be exploited to compromise system security, data integrity, or availability. Vulnerabilities are typically assigned a unique identifier (e.g., CVE ID), a severity score (e.g., CVSS), and may be associated with known exploits. In the MSP context, vulnerabilities are detected through scans, threat intelligence feeds, or vendor advisories and are often tracked and mitigated using patching, configuration changes, or compensating controls.
prompt_examples: List all critical vulnerabilities detected on devices in the ‘Healthcare West’ tenant.
Has the CVE-2024-23978 vulnerability been patched across all cloud servers?
Generate a vulnerability report for third-party software used in finance-related sites.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to a “Vulnerability,” the AI agent will:
actions: Look up the vulnerability using known identifiers or descriptive keywords
Query vulnerability scan results or correlated security event data
Map the vulnerability to affected software, devices, or configurations
Check remediation status: patched, mitigated, or unaddressed
Recommend or trigger remediation actions if authorized

recommendation: Use Vulnerability to identify and track security weaknesses. Specify identifiers or context for precise detection and remediation.

definition: A Warranty refers to the contractual period during which a hardware asset (e.g., server, laptop, disk) is covered for repairs, replacements, or support by the manufacturer or vendor. In the MSP context, warranty information helps inform lifecycle management, asset planning, and service prioritization. Tracking warranty status enables technicians to escalate hardware issues appropriately and manage risk around unsupported devices.
prompt_examples: Which devices have warranties expiring in the next 30 days?
Is the disk in device ‘HR-LT-004’ still under warranty?
List all out-of-warranty servers in the ‘EMEA’ region.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt includes “Warranty,” the AI agent will:
actions: Look up asset metadata to determine the warranty start and end dates
Flag any expired or soon-to-expire warranties
Associate warranty status with asset age, performance issues, or incident trends
Suggest replacement recommendations or notify stakeholders based on policy
Optionally pull warranty verification from vendor portals if integrated

recommendation: Use Warranty to track support coverage periods for hardware assets. Specify asset and timeframe for accurate status and planning.

definition: A Webhook is a user-defined HTTP callback that automatically sends real-time data or event notifications from one system to another when a specified condition is met. Unlike APIs that require polling, webhooks push information immediately to an external endpoint. In MSP and IT environments, webhooks are often used to trigger workflows, sync systems, log events, or alert technicians based on changes in tickets, devices, backups, or policies.
relationships: Webhook sendsDataTo External System or Agent
Webhook isConfiguredIn Platform, Policy, or Integration
Webhook mayContain Payload with JSON or XML Format
Webhook isLoggedIn Audit Log or Integration History
prompt_examples: Create a webhook to notify the external ticketing system when a device goes offline.
List all active webhooks configured for backup failure events.
Disable the webhook that posts alerts to the incident response Slack channel.
What payload does the policy webhook send when a patch job completes?

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to a “Webhook,” the AI agent will:
actions: Retrieve the webhook configuration, including trigger event, URL, and payload format
Monitor for relevant events and evaluate webhook triggering conditions
Send structured data to the designated external endpoint
Handle success or failure responses and retry logic if applicable
Log webhook activity, errors, and payload content for audit and troubleshooting

recommendation: Use Webhook to enable real-time event-driven integrations. Clearly define triggers, targets, and payload formats for reliable operation.

definition: WMI (Windows Management Instrumentation) is a Microsoft technology that provides a standardized interface for accessing and managing data about Windows-based systems. It allows scripts, agents, and monitoring tools to query system information such as hardware status, software inventory, services, processes, and configuration settings. In MSP environments, WMI is widely used for device discovery, performance monitoring, remote execution, and automation.
relationships: WMI isQueriedBy Agent, Script, or Monitoring Tool
WMI exposes SystemInfo, Metrics, or ConfigurationData
WMI mayBeUsedIn Discovery, Alerting, or Reporting
WMI isSecuredBy User Permissions and Firewall Rules
prompt_examples: Query WMI for disk health and available storage on all domain-joined devices.
Which devices have WMI disabled or returning errors?
Use WMI to collect a list of installed applications across the fleet.
Alert if WMI reports CPU usage over 90 percent for 10 minutes.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to “WMI,” the AI agent will:
actions: Establish a connection to the target Windows device using proper credentials and network access
Execute the WMI query to retrieve requested information
Parse and format results for reporting, monitoring, or policy evaluation
Log WMI query outcomes, including failures or access issues
Respect configured permissions, throttling rules, and audit requirements for WMI usage

recommendation: Use WMI for Windows system management, ensuring proper permissions and network access are configured.

definition: A Workflow is a structured sequence of tasks or activities designed to accomplish a specific objective within a system or process. In the DevOps Infrastructure Ontology, a workflow represents the orchestration of actions, often automated, that manage and control various aspects of IT infrastructure and software development. Workflows are essential for ensuring consistency, efficiency, and repeatability in operations.
relationships: Workflow interactsWith Resources such as Devices, Services, or Applications
prompt_examples: Initiate the onboarding workflow for a new employee in the ‘Sales’ department.
What workflows are currently active for patch management across all servers?
Modify the backup workflow to include encryption before data transfer.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to a “Workflow,” the AI agent will:
actions: Identify the specific workflow based on context and naming conventions.
Execute the defined sequence of tasks, ensuring each step is completed successfully.
Monitor the workflow’s progress and handle exceptions or errors as defined.
Log the execution details for auditing and compliance purposes.
Provide feedback or notifications upon completion or if intervention is required.

recommendation: Use Workflow to automate structured sequences of IT tasks. Clearly define triggers, steps, and outcomes for reliability.

definition: An Active User is a user account that has recently authenticated, initiated a session, performed actions, or otherwise engaged with a system, service, or platform within a defined timeframe. The term is used to distinguish between currently engaged or recently engaged users and those that are inactive, suspended, or dormant. In MSP and IT environments, active users are tracked for licensing, security auditing, capacity planning, and automation targeting.
relationships: Active User isAuthenticatedBy Directory or Identity Provider
Active User interactsWith Application, Service, or Device
Active User isTrackedIn Session Log, Audit Log, or Usage Report
Active User mayBeAssignedTo Role, Policy, or License
Active User contributesTo Usage Metrics or Billing
prompt_examples: List all active users across all client tenants in the past 7 days.
Trigger a password reset workflow for all active users with elevated privileges.
Which active users accessed the backup management console yesterday?
Export a report of all active users by site and department.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to an “Active User,” the AI agent will:
actions: Query the user directory, session logs, or activity metrics to identify accounts meeting the active criteria
Apply filters such as time range, role, location, or group
Correlate activity with licensing, authentication, or policy enforcement data
Return the list of matching users or perform the requested action on their behalf
Log all queries and actions for auditing or compliance purposes

definition: ARR (Annual Recurring Revenue) is the total value of recurring revenue from subscriptions or service contracts normalized over a one-year period. It represents the predictable income that an MSP or SaaS business expects to receive annually from active customers. ARR is a key metric for evaluating long-term growth, customer retention, and business valuation.
relationships: ARR isTiedTo Subscriber, Contract, or Service Plan
ARR isTrackedIn Financial System or CRM
ARR isImpactedBy Renewals, Upgrades, or Churn
ARR isReportedIn KPIs or Growth Dashboards
prompt_examples: What is the current ARR across all managed security services?
Compare ARR by client tier and contract length.
How has ARR changed year-over-year for the healthcare vertical?
Generate an ARR forecast based on current MRR and pipeline data.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to “ARR,” the AI agent will:
actions: Retrieve MRR and related subscription data to calculate ARR
Segment ARR by service, customer, or region if specified
Identify factors influencing ARR growth or decline, such as churn or expansion
Generate reports, dashboards, or financial summaries for strategic planning
Log ARR calculations and forecasting activities for auditing or executive review

definition: A Browser is a client application used to access and interact with content and services on the World Wide Web. It renders web pages, processes scripts, and facilitates communication with remote servers using protocols such as HTTPS. In MSP and IT environments, browsers are used to access web-based portals, dashboards, APIs, and SaaS platforms. They may also be managed through policies for security, compliance, and performance.
relationships: Browser accesses Web Page, Portal, or API
Browser runs on Endpoint, Workstation, or Virtual Desktop
Browser isControlledBy Policy, Extension, or Configuration
Browser isMonitoredFor Usage, Version, or Threats
Browser mayBeIsolatedBy Remote Browser or Sandbox
prompt_examples: Ensure all browsers in the environment are running the latest secure version.
Restrict browser access to approved domains only for student users.
Report which browsers are used most frequently across all managed endpoints.
Deploy the web security extension to all Chrome browsers.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to a “Browser,” the AI agent will:
actions: Identify installed browser applications on the target endpoint or environment
Retrieve version, configuration, and extension data for compliance and security
Apply browser-related policies or updates as needed
Monitor for unsafe browsing activity, outdated versions, or non-compliant settings
Log browser-related actions or events for auditing and reporting

definition: An Incident is an unplanned event or disruption that affects the normal operation of a service, system, or asset and requires investigation, response, or resolution. Incidents can range from device failures and service outages to security breaches or policy violations. In MSP and IT environments, incidents are tracked through ticketing systems and are often subject to escalation paths, service-level agreements (SLAs), and post-resolution analysis.
relationships: Incident isReportedBy User, Agent, or Monitoring Tool
Incident isTrackedIn Ticketing System or Incident Queue
Incident isAssignedTo Technician, Team, or AI Agent
Incident isLinkedTo Alert, Asset, or Service
Incident mayTrigger Workflow, Notification, or Escalation
prompt_examples: List all open incidents affecting the backup infrastructure.
Escalate critical incidents that remain unresolved after 2 hours.
Which incidents were triggered by failed patch deployments?
Generate a monthly report of all incidents by site and root cause.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to an “Incident,” the AI agent will:
actions: Search the incident management system for relevant records based on status, severity, or source
Retrieve and summarize incident details including timestamps, affected assets, and resolution steps
Initiate workflows such as assignment, escalation, or notification based on defined rules
Update the incident record with actions taken or insights generated
Log all interactions and changes for auditing and service reporting

definition: MRR (Monthly Recurring Revenue) is the predictable, recurring portion of revenue generated from active subscriptions or service contracts on a monthly basis. It reflects the value of ongoing client relationships and is commonly used to track growth, retention, and financial health in MSP and SaaS business models.
relationships: MRR isTiedTo Service Plan, Contract, or License
MRR isTrackedIn Billing System or CRM
MRR isAffectedBy Upgrades, Cancellations, or Discounts
MRR isReportedIn Financial Dashboards or KPIs
prompt_examples: What is the total MRR for managed backup services this month?
List all clients contributing more than $1,000 in MRR.
How did MRR change after the quarterly contract renewals?
Break down MRR by service type and client tier.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to “MRR,” the AI agent will:
actions: Retrieve current and historical MRR data from billing or subscription systems
Segment MRR by client, service, or plan for analysis or reporting
Identify changes in MRR due to churn, expansion, or pricing adjustments
Generate dashboards, alerts, or forecasts based on MRR trends
Log financial metrics and reporting actions for auditing and business review

definition: PII (Personally Identifiable Information) refers to any data that can be used to identify an individual, either on its own or when combined with other information. This includes names, email addresses, phone numbers, government IDs, financial data, and biometric records. In MSP and IT environments, PII must be handled with strict security and compliance controls to meet privacy regulations such as GDPR, HIPAA, or CCPA.
relationships: PII isStoredIn Database, CRM, or File System
PII isProtectedBy Encryption, Access Control, or DLP Policy
PII isSubjectTo Compliance Regulation or Data Policy
PII mayBeAccessedBy User, Technician, or External System
PII isMonitoredFor Breach, Misuse, or Unauthorized Access
prompt_examples: Scan file shares for unencrypted PII such as SSNs and credit card numbers.
Which backup sets contain customer PII subject to GDPR?
Apply DLP policies to restrict email transmission of PII.
Report all access to PII records in the past 30 days.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to “PII,” the AI agent will:
actions: Locate data sources likely to contain PII based on content types or metadata
Identify and classify PII using pattern recognition, tags, or predefined rules
Evaluate whether storage, access, and transmission comply with security and privacy policies
Trigger alerts or remediation workflows in the event of unauthorized access or exposure
Log all actions involving PII discovery, access, or handling for audit and compliance tracking

definition: A Policy is a defined set of rules or configurations that govern how systems, devices, users, or services should behave or be managed within an environment. Policies enforce standards related to security, compliance, automation, performance, and access. In MSP and IT operations, policies are applied to endpoints, users, or sites to ensure consistent behavior, streamline operations, and meet organizational or regulatory requirements.
relationships: Policy isAppliedTo Device, User, Group, or Site
Policy isCreatedBy Admin, Technician, or AI Agent
Policy defines Rules, Settings, or Thresholds
Policy mayTrigger Alert, Action, or Workflow
prompt_examples: Apply the antivirus policy to all unmanaged Windows devices.
Which policies are currently assigned to the HR department endpoints?
Create a new patching policy with a 72-hour compliance window.
Alert if a device deviates from the baseline security policy.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to a “Policy,” the AI agent will:
actions: Retrieve the policy definition and scope, including affected objects and configuration details
Validate the policy’s applicability to the specified targets
Apply the policy settings or rules to the defined devices, users, or services
Monitor for compliance and trigger alerts or remediation if deviations occur
Log all policy applications, changes, and exceptions for auditing and reporting

definition: Shadow IT refers to the use of software, hardware, cloud services, or other technology solutions within an organization without formal approval, visibility, or oversight from the IT department. This includes unmanaged SaaS tools, personal devices, and unauthorized data storage or sharing platforms. In MSP and IT environments, shadow IT poses risks related to security, compliance, data loss, and operational inefficiencies.
relationships: Shadow IT isUsedBy End User or Department
Shadow IT bypasses IT Policy or Approval Workflow
Shadow IT mayExpose PII or Sensitive Data
Shadow IT isDetectedBy Monitoring Tool or AI Agent
Shadow IT isReportedIn Risk Assessment or Compliance Audit
prompt_examples: Identify all SaaS applications in use that are not approved by IT.
Alert when new devices connect to the network without registration.
Generate a report on potential shadow IT usage by department.
What shadow IT risks were flagged during the last endpoint scan?

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to “Shadow IT,” the AI agent will:
actions: Monitor network, device, and usage data to detect unauthorized tools or services
Compare discovered assets against approved technology inventories or whitelists
Classify shadow IT by risk level, user group, and type of service
Trigger alerts, initiate risk remediation workflows, or generate compliance reports
Log all detections and actions related to shadow IT for auditing and review

definition: SSO (Single Sign-On) is an authentication mechanism that allows users to access multiple systems or applications with a single set of login credentials. It streamlines user access while reducing password fatigue and improving security through centralized identity management. In MSP and IT environments, SSO is often integrated with identity providers (IdPs) such as Azure AD, Okta, or Google Workspace to control access across cloud and on-premises services.
relationships: SSO providesAccessTo Application, Portal, or Service
SSO isGovernedBy Authentication Policy or Role
SSO mayBeIntegratedWith MFA or Directory Service
prompt_examples: Enable SSO for all technicians using Azure AD.
List applications configured to support SSO for this client.
Report failed SSO login attempts in the past 24 hours.
Is SSO enforced for access to the backup management console?

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to “SSO,” the AI agent will:
actions: Retrieve SSO configuration details for the relevant identity provider and service
Validate user identity and access permissions through the SSO process
Log successful or failed login attempts for auditing and security monitoring
Trigger conditional access workflows based on role, location, or device compliance
Report on SSO usage, errors, and integration status across environments

definition: A Subscriber is an entity — typically a user, client, tenant, or system — that is actively enrolled in or assigned to a service, product, or data stream. Subscribers receive notifications, updates, access, or resources according to their subscription level or role. In MSP and IT environments, subscribers are often associated with licensing, usage metrics, automation triggers, or event-driven integrations.
relationships: Subscriber isAssignedTo Service, Plan, or Policy
Subscriber isTrackedIn CRM, Directory, or Subscription System
Subscriber mayReceive Notification, Report, or Update
Subscriber mayBeBoundTo SLA, License, or Billing Agreement
Subscriber interactsWith Portal, Agent, or API
prompt_examples: List all active subscribers to the endpoint monitoring service.
Send system health reports to all Gold-level subscribers.
Which subscribers are over their cloud storage limit?
Deactivate subscribers with expired licenses.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to a “Subscriber,” the AI agent will:
actions: Identify the subscriber entity and retrieve associated metadata such as service tier, contact info, and usage status
Determine eligibility or compliance based on policies, thresholds, or entitlements
Perform requested actions such as notifications, provisioning, suspension, or escalation
Update subscriber records and log activity for auditing or billing purposes

definition: A User is an individual or system identity that interacts with IT services, applications, or infrastructure. Each user is typically associated with a unique account and may be assigned roles, permissions, policies, or resources. In MSP and IT environments, users are managed through identity systems, directory services, or RMM platforms to control access, monitor activity, and enforce security.
relationships: User isAuthenticatedBy Identity Provider or Directory
User isAssignedTo Role, Group, or Policy
User interactsWith Device, Application, or Portal
User isMonitoredFor Activity, Access, or Compliance
User mayBeLinkedTo License, Ticket, or Alert
prompt_examples: List all users with administrator privileges in the RMM platform.
Deactivate users who have been inactive for more than 90 days.
What devices are currently assigned to user jsmith@clientdomain.com?
Apply MFA policy to all remote users in the finance department.

agent_execution.interpretation: When a prompt refers to a “User,” the AI agent will:
actions: Retrieve the user account and associated metadata from the relevant directory or system
Determine the user’s roles, group memberships, permissions, and recent activity
Perform actions such as enabling, disabling, updating, or notifying the user
Enforce policies related to access, compliance, or security
Log all user-related actions for audit, reporting, or troubleshooting
